course.subject: LABU
course.name: Effective Communication in Business
course.description: The course activates students' previously acquired English language skills into a useful managerial communication toolkit targeted toward specific business applications and strategies. Students will learn how to be an effective communicator in the global workplace. The course is designed and structured to address the learning needs of students in job-seeking and in their early careers. Students will have opportunities to learn and practice how to succeed in business writing, presentations, interviews, meetings, and collaborative assignments. The course also introduces students to strategies for handling the communication challenges which fresh graduates can expect in the global workplace. For students who have this course as a program requirement.
course.prerequisites: CORE 1403 OR CORE 1404 OR LANG 1003 (prior to 2022-23)
course.exclusions: LABU 2020 (prior to 2019-20)

reviews.author: ebeneezer's
reviews.title: Assigned team dictates whether you will enjoy the course.
reviews.comment_content: 1 practice case and 2 graded cases. Case prompts are pretty ambiguous because they are related to company culture and employees relations. Teaches fairly basic and common approaches to business challenges, imagine ted talk but live, and with a PowerPoint and occasional jokes.
reviews.comment_teaching: Levi is a US-educated North Cali instructor. Don't worry he will keep reminding you about that throughout the course. Quite engaging speaker but make these dramatic pauses in between sentences to create the mysterious atmosphere in the classroom.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading cannot be more vague, if you are hoping to get A range, better laugh at his jokes and act American. If you get a B, it's normal. Majority of people in my year are extremely dissatisfied with what they got in the end, and some appealed but that won't work, unless he likes you. If english is your native tounge, he's going to like you, unless you try to act smart and have too many things to say. Just put his comments or suggestions into your actual deliverables and you'll be fine. Try not to go for too innovative ideas, go for stable but well elaborated. Include all the details you can and finally, be confident and don't be scared to speak up.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is mid, most of the time no work because the in-class discussions requires zero prep. Maybe during case presentations you and your team will have to grind for a bit. Enjoy before you need to take the actual GBUS courses, this is only a taste of what they will be, and how capable those courses are in occupying your entire week.
